title-group.article-title: Some Contributions of Existential Phenomenology to the Philosophy of Natural Science

ref.mixed-citation: Patrick Heelan, "Hermeneutical Phenomenology and the Philosophy of Science," Ch. 4 in "Gadamer and Hermeneutics", ed. by Hugh J. Silverman, forthcoming from Methuen, and by Joseph Kockelmans, "On the Problem of Truth in the Sciences," Proceedings and Addresses of the American Philosophical As- sociation, supplement to vol. 61:1, (1985), pp, 5-26.
Heelan's Space Perception and the Philosophy of Science (Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press, 1983)
Kockelmans' Heidegger and Science, Vol. I. Current Continental Research (Washington D. C: University Press of America, 1985).
Thomas Kuhn, The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, 2nd ed. (Chicago: University of Chicago Press), p. 170.
Larry Laudan, Progress and Its Problems (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1977), p. 125.
Thomas Kuhn's "Reflections on my Critics" in Lakatos, I., and Musgrave, A., eds., Criticism and the Growth of Knowledge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1970), p. 264.
Bas van Fraassen, The Scientific Image (Oxford: The Clarendon Press, 1980).
Nancy Cartwright, How the Laws of Physics Lie (Oxford: The Clarendon Press, 1983).
the excellent anthologies, Scientific Realism, ed. by Jarrett Leplin (Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press, 1984)
Images of Science, ed. by Paul M. Churchland and Clifford Hooker, (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1985).
Richard Rorty, "Solidarity or Objectivity," In Post-Analytic Philosophy, ed. by John Rajchman and Cornel West (New York: Columbia University Press, 1986), pp. 3-5.

Marjorie Grene, "Empiricism and the Philosophy of Science, or n Dogmas of Empiricism," in Epistemology, Methodology, and The Social Sciences, ed. by R. S. Cohen and M. W. Wartofsky (Dordrecht: Reidel, 1983), pp. 93 ff.
Martin Heidegger, Being and Time, tr. by Macquarrie and Robinson (London: SCM Press, 1962), sec. 69 (b)
Edmund Husserl, The Crisis of European Science, tr. by David Carr (Evanston: Northwestern University Press, 1970).
Maurice Merleau-Ponty, The Phenomenology of Perception, tr. by Colin Smith (New York: The Humanities Press, 1962), p. viii.
Maurice Merleau-Ponty, "The Primacy of Perception," in The Primacy of Perception, ed. by James Edie (Evanston: Northwestern University Press, 1964), p. 25.
Ibid., p. 16.

Marjorie Grene, "Perception, Interpretation, and the Sciences: Toward a New Philosophy of Science," in Evolution at the Crossroads: The New Biology and the New Philosophy of Science, ed. by David Depew and Bruce Weber (Cambridge, Mass.: Massachussetts Institute of Technology Press, 1985), pp. 1-20.
my "Marjorie Grene and the Phenomenon of Life," Proceedings of the Philosophy of Science Association 1984, Vol. 2 (1985), pp. 354-364.
N. R. Hanson, Patterns of Discovery (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1958), pp. 85 ff.
Is There a Logic of Discovery?," in Current Issues in the Philosophy of Science, ed. by Herbert Feigl and Grover Maxwell (New York: Holt, Rinehart, and Winston, 1961), pp. 20-35.
van Fraassen puts the issue in The Scientific Image, op. cit, pp. 10, 153-157, 197-198.
"On the Problem of Truth in the Sciences," op. cit.
Merleau-Ponty's hints, "The Primacy of Perception," pp. 19-21
"Phenomenology and the Sciences of Man," pp. 65-77
The Primacy of Perception, op. cit.
Ernan McMullin offers in "A Case for Scientific Realism," in Jarrett Leplin's Scientific Realism, op. cit.
Hilary Putnam, "Two Philosophical Perspectives," in Reason, Truth, and History (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1981).
Patrick Heelan, "Natural Science as a Hermeneutic of Instrumentation, "Philosophy of Science, vol. 50 (1983), pp. 181-204.

Patrick Heelan in several papers, among them "Hermeneutics of Experimental Science in the Context of the Life World," in Don Ihde and Richard Zaner, eds., Interdisciplinary Phenomenology (The Hague:Nijhoff, 1975), pp. 7-50
"Natural Science as a Hermeneutic of Instrumentation," Philosophy of Science, op. cit.
